awd_titl_txt: Annual Conference of the Society for Social Studies of Science:  Travel Grants for Graduate Student Participants
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

This award is to support a series of conferences; it provides support for graduate student travel to upcoming meetings of Society for Social Studies of Science. Funding will be used to support travel over the next five years beginning in 2016 and ending in 2020. Meeting locations are as follows: 2016 (Barcelona, Spain), 2017 (Boston, MA), 2018 (Sydney, Australia), 2019 (tentatively, New Orleans, LA), and 2020 (to be determined). Participation in at least some of these conferences will enable graduate students to professionally network, receive feedback from senior scholars in their field, remain abreast of developments in their area, and disseminate the results of their own research. The travel awards will also be used to ensure the participation of underrepresented minorities; the inclusion of such groups will serve an important selection criterion among others in distributing travel awards. More generally, this support will contribute to the growth of a strong science and technology workforce, a workforce that is made all the more innovative and competitive through the involvement of underrepresented groups.

Technical Summary 

The 4S annual meeting brings together an international and interdisciplinary group of scholars who share the common goal of understanding the development of science, technology, and medicine and the way they interact within a social context. Relatively new and impactful research as well as theoretical ideas on these topics are shared and discussed at the annual meeting. Supporting graduate student participation in such an atmosphere is beneficial not only for the professional socialization of the students themselves, but also for maintaining intellectual vitality within the discipline; graduate students frequently introduce fresh perspectives on new and old intellectual problems. The impact of graduate student participation in the annual meeting also extends beyond the field since most them will go on to work in an academic environment, a research institute or in some policy making body. Facilitating their attendance at the annual meeting will facilitate their becoming engaged and informed teachers, researchers, and policy makers, potentially impacting countless undergraduate students and informing the direction of social policy.

por.por_cntn:
Over the period covered by this award, 412 graduate students were provided travel funds to attend the annual meeting of the Society for Social Studies of Science.  Individual awards ranged from a low of $50 to a high of $1,000 based on need.  There is a competitive selection process designed to support broad representation across the field. Students are required to provide follow-up documentation on their experience.

The funds used to assist graduate student travel were indispensible for the attendance of many of those who received an award.  Conference participation is crucial for the intellectual and professional development of graduate students as it provides them with an opportunity to learn from their peers, to receive critical feedback on their own research, and to establish connections with others that may lead to future collaborations. In addition to providing graduate students with the financial means to attend the annual meeting, a number of these same students participated in the mentorship program at the annual meeting.  As part of the mentorship program, many graduate students receiving travel awards were paired with a faculty member at the annual meeting sharing a similar set of research interests.  This program provided them the opportunity to engage in informal scientific exchange and to receive general academic and career guidance.

Several broader impacts have been associated with the use of NSF travel funds by graduate students.  First, conference participation is essential for the professional development of junior scholars as it provides the unique opportunity to interact with colleagues from diverse backgrounds.  Second, conference participation exposes junior scholars to innovative research, providing the intellectual ferment necessary for their intellectual maturation. Third, conference participation by graduate students increases the visibility of research coming out of the United States to a diverse and international community of scholars.  Finally, the presence of junior scholars at the annual meeting benefits the Society itself as their active participation provides the increased vigor and vitality needed to prevent intellectual stagnation within the field. Indeed, these funds have brought students into the field who are now leaders in STS education, research and innovation.
